text: [Music]
many modern musical instruments are
cumbersome or have a lot of parts some
need a stand or a stool but the kahone
is a drum a stand and a seat all in one
convenient box and this Simplicity may
be key to its journey across continents
and cultures to become one of the most
popular percussion instruments in the
world today
The kohon Story begins in West Africa
whose indigenous people had Rich musical
Traditions centered on drumming and
dancing when many of them were captured
and brought to the Americas as slaves
they brought this culture with them but
without their native instruments they
had to
improvise African slaves in coastal Peru
didn't have the materials or the
opportunity to craft one of their
traditional drums such as a Jambi or a
dundun but what they did did have were
plenty of shipping crates not only were
these readily accessible but their
inconspicuous appearance may have helped
get around laws prohibiting slaves from
playing
music early Peruvian C horns consisted
of a simple box with five thick wooden
sides the sixth side made of a thinner
sheet of wood would be used as the
Striking surface or more commonly known
as the tapa a sound hole was also cut
into the back to allow the sound to
escape
as an AFR Peruvian culture developed and
new forms of Music and Dance such as
zamak qua Veo and Lando were born the
kahon became a dedicated musical
instrument in its own right early
modifications involved simply bending
the planks of the box to tweak the sound
and when the abolition of slavery
introduced the kahon to a broader
population more improvisation and
experimentation soon
followed perhaps the person most
responsible for introducing the kahon to
European audiences was Spanish flamco
guitarist Paco de
luia when touring in Peru in
1977 he and his percussionist rabim
dantas discovered the kahon and brought
it back to Spain recognizing its
potential for use in flamco music by
stretching guitar strings along the
inside of the tapa the flamco musicians
were able to create a buzz- likee snare
sound combined with the regular Bas tone
this gave the Kon a sound close to a
basic drum
set the Kon quickly caught on not only
becoming standard in flamco but being
used in genres like folk jazz blues and
Rock today many specialized goons are
manufactured some with adjustable
strings some with multiple plane
surfaces and some with a snare
mechanism but the basic concept Remains
the Same and the story of the Kohan
shows that the simplest things can have
the most amazing potential when you
think outside and inside the Box
